sentences:
Le Dr Gordon Moore était le directeur de la recherche et du développement chez Fairchild lorsqu'il a écrit l'article, " Entassement de plus de
composants sur des circuits intégrés » publié dans le numéro du 19 avril 1965 de ÉLECTRONIQUE .

Non seulement les fabricants sont confrontés à un défi de rendement de densité de défauts qui a une corrélation directe avec la taille de la matrice, comme vous pouvez le voir sur le graphique suivant , les coûts fixes associés à la conception et à la mise en production d'un nouveau circuit intégré monolithique complexe ont grimpé en flèche avec les progrès de la technologie de fabrication.

Intel a une longue histoire de présentation plus conservatrice de ses nœuds de processus de fabrication, ce qui explique pourquoi sa densité de transistors à 22 nm est approximativement la même que celle de Fujitsu pour son processeur SPARC à 20 nm.  Alors que l'époque des microprocesseurs approchant la taille d'un timbre-poste est révolue, les progrès de la technologie de fabrication continuent de permettre une densité de transistors de plus en plus élevée.

Le programme va au-delà de l'exploitation des avantages de l'incorporation de nœuds de fabrication hétérogènes pour incorporer également des matériaux hétérogènes dans une conception de Chiplet.  (4) La magie de la loi de Moore était que le coût de fabrication par transistor diminuerait beaucoup plus que les coûts fixes n'augmentaient à mesure que la technologie de fabrication progressait.

Cependant, lorsqu'il est associé à la prophétie de la loi de Moore qui prédisait correctement que le coût par transistor sur un circuit intégré chuterait rapidement à mesure que la technologie de fabrication progressait, le moule du modèle commercial des semi-conducteurs a été coulé et les capitaux ont afflué librement dans l'industrie.

stories.title: La loi de Moore est morte - Vive le Chiplet !

en.body:
Dr. Gordon Moore was the director of research and development at Fairchild when he wrote the article, "Enhancing more than one of the most important things to do.
The 1965 ELECTRONIQUE , which was published in the 1965 issue of integrated circuits, was published by Dr. Carver Mead de Caltech as the "Moore Act" prediction. Very few people understand the essence of Moore's law or know the myth of tangent projections that Dr. Moore made in this article relatively short; they included personal computers, automatic orders for cars, communications equipment, and the  It was a very personal and many other innovations that at the time could have been seen as science fiction to some readers. Among Dr. Moore's projections for integrated circuits (CI), there was a 1975 economy that could dictate that up to 65,000 XNUMX components could be pushed on a single silicon pump. This took a few years more than projection, but the first 64-K DRAM (DRAM) of 64 Kos was released in 1977 with 65,536 XNUMX transistors on a "one-size-fits-all silicon pump." This is a remarkable projection since the first commercially viable DRAM was introduced in 1970 ; five years after the publication of Dr. Moore's article. The essence of Moore's Law Although there are a number of projections included in Moore's Law and almost all of them have been done to a reasonable degree, there are two projections that are "the gas" of Moore's Law. If we do a little computing, we can add color to these projections. Here are two quotations from the original article of 1965 and my extrapolation of the predictions. "The complexity of the minimum costs of the components has increased at a rate of about two factors per year. In the short term, we can certainly expect that this rate will continue to rise. In the longer term, the rate of increase is somewhat more uncertain, although there is no reason to believe that it will not be nearly constant for at least 10 years. This suggests that over the next ten years, we will see the density of transistors (components) increase by an factor of approximately 1.024 XNUMX. "In 1970, one can expect that the cost of manufacturing per component is only one tenth of the current cost." This provides that if the density of transistors (components) doubles each year, the cost per component will decrease at an annual rate of about 37%. This is important to understand, so let us take a moment to go through the calculations. With each doubling of the density of the components, manufacturing costs are increasing, but Dr Moore correctly expects that these higher costs will be offset by the annual doubling of the density. The result is a 37% reduction in net costs per transistor (component) which results in a 90% reduction in costs in five years and a 99% reduction in costs in ten years. Following this ten-year race until 1975, which worked very similar to Moore's law projections, Dr. Moore re-established expectations for a double-digit transistrant every 18 to 24 months compared to each year. Following these remarkable advances, if you live in the middle class or above the middle class in a developed country, there is a very good chance that you are a 'trillionary transit' - that with all the electronic tricks you have, you have more than a billion 1999. So far, we are - A case study When I entered the semi-conductor industry in 1976, the dominant DRAM device was the 16Kb (16K x 1) Mosttek MK4116 (Intel had 2116, but Mosta was the main supplier). Its electricity consumption (active state) was approximately 0.432 watts (432 mW). Due to the large size of boxes used in 1976, you could only install about 1.5 devices per square foot of printed circuit card surface (PCB). While I remember, the MK4116 sold for about $10 (dollars in 1976) in volume. (1) While DRAM 64Kb was out in 1977, its cost per bit remained higher than the DRAM 16Kb until 1980. If we extract this data, we can see that the typical 16 Go (16 Go x 8) memory used in the general public PC today would cost about $80 million for memory chips (400 million dollars in 2021), requiring a PC of about 300 million dollars, 300,000  35,000 square feet (more than the 3,500,000 0.10-square-foot hall at Grand Central) and would consume about 250,000 XNUMX power watts. At XNUMX $ by KWh, it would cost more than XNUMX XNUMX per month to feed this memory card. (2) To simplify things, all calculations are based only on the 8,000,000 4116 16 DRAM MKXNUMX that would be necessary to provide XNUMX Go memory. In addition to these, a myriad of additional passive and active components would also be necessary. These components are not included in any of the calculations. Today, you can buy a 16-go DRAM module for a portable computer in a retail store for about $40 (about $8,1975), or about the size of your index and consume less than 3 watts of energy. This is easily powered by a portable computer battery, but at $0.10 per KWh, the monthly cost would be a little over $0.20. Obviously, from so many points of view (cost, heat, size and reliability to name only a few), it would have been not only impractical, but literally impossible to build a 16 Go DRAM memory card in 1976. Of course, that would not have been useful. However, the microprocessors available in 1976 could only be sent to 64 Ko of memory. However, this illustration of the progress made by Moore's law since I joined the industry is only a case study that illustrates the path that industry has taken. If we adjust inflation, our data indicate that the progress under Moore's Act has resulted in a 99.9999995% reduction in costs (i.e. 30% per year for 45 years) and a reduction in 99.9999993% of energy consumption. And when you combine these advances with an even more significant reduction in the required surface, you can better appreciate what Moore's law has made possible, but above all, practical and affordable. If it is quite simple to exaggerate the progress made by semi-conductors that have reduced the cost of DRAM by bit by a factor of about 10 million, it is much more difficult to estimate improvements for processors. summations from industry that are much more intelligent than I have said that, considering the progress of the computing architecture that has been made possible by Moore's law, the economic efficiency of integrated processor circuits has improved from more than  A billion since the introduction of 4004 in 1971. . Although it is difficult to visualize and quantify these improvements with figures, it is very easy to prove that even a mid-range smartphone today has more computing power than the entire NASA had when the Apollo 11 mission landed astronauts on the same planet. in 1969. that next time you'll have a question in Siri, Alexa or Google... The economy of transistors There are all kinds of fantastic words you can use to describe various business models, but I like to keep things as simple as possible. In any business model, you can divide the costs between "fixes" (capital) and "variables" (marginals). If the model is heavily weighed by variable expenditures, there is little scale (the leverage effect) and profitability follows a fairly linear line with volume. However, if the model is heavily weighed by fixed costs, the model is changing (sortically) and profitability is rising significantly as the volume increases. For example, if you had to build oil, you should build a platform and make all the capital investment necessary to make oil (fixed costs), but once it is built and oil starts to flow, the costs to maintain this flow (the cost of the oil) will be (l) are very low. In this economic model, high fixed costs are incurred on the oil barrels that are pumped. The obvious conclusion is that the more oil barrels are produced, the lower the total cost per barrel (the fixed costs are reduced on more than one barrel of oil). The slightly less obvious conclusion is that the " marginal cost" of the next barile produced is very low. Since the marginal (variable) cost represents the total increase in the cost of producing an additional unit (bar) and no additional fixed cost is required, only variable costs are taken into account. Of course, given these data, the volume is important TRT in commercial models that operate with high fixed costs and low variable costs. This classic example of a high-cost/low variable business model is more or less aligned with what we see in the classic business model of semi-conductors. It costs a lot of money to open a line of manufacturing of high-tech semi-conductors (made in tens of billions of dollars today) and the design of a relatively complex integrated circuit for a high-end manufacturing process (5 nm) could easily cost a i-million. However, once the manufacturing plant is operational and the IC is in production, the marginal cost of manufacturing the next silicon chip is low compared to these fixed costs. The semi-conductor industry has a huge advantage over the oil industry; unlike oil where the final supply is limited (received reserves), there is a relatively unending supply of low-cost silicon (the basic material of most semi-containing  ) which means that there are strong reasons to keep prices down to stimulate demand and produce more volume. This phenomenon is demonstrated in the data. Bell Labs produced exactly one transistor in his laboratory in 1947 and it took several years before a catch was produced for limited applications. In 2022, only 75 years later, the semi-conductor industry will literally produce hundreds of billions of transistors for each man, woman and child on the ground and sell them in the form of integrated circuits for infinite fractions of one hundred. There are probably a number of stories behind the launch of this incredible trend towards growth, but one of my favorites was written by George Gilder in his book, Microcosme As history was told by George, Fairchild Symonicator sold a transistor (not only The amount of part 1211) in relatively low volumes to military clients for $150 each. With a cost of about $100, Fairchild has made a good profit. However, given the strict military specifications, there were still spare parts that did not meet the client's requirements. To find a home to these transistors, Jerry Sanders, who had recently been promoted to head the Fairchild general public marketing group, was charged with finding a buyer willing to pay $5 for the rejections. He found voluntary buyers, but in 1963, when the CCP required all new TVs to include UHF reception, a huge new market opportunity was opened. (3) Jerry Sanders then left Fairchild to start Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) The problem here was that even at $5, the 1211 general public version could not compete with the innovative metal-carrying tube of RCA called the Nuvist TV commercial, which was urs for only $1.05. Sanders tried all possible angles to circumvent the $3.95 price difference - the consumer 1211 could be directly fed to the PCB by avoiding the use of a Nuvistor and the transistor was clearly more reliable. However, he simply could not conclude the case. Since the potential television market in 1963 was about 10 million units per year; Sanders visited Fairchild's headquarters in Mountain View and met Dr. Robert Noyce at his home in the hills of Los Altos. He initially hesitated to ask for the $1.05 price he needed to complete the case, but once Sanders described the opportunity, Dr. Noyce accepted the application without delay and after a brief reflection, approved it. Sanders returned to Zenith and reserved the first consumer order of $1,211 for $1.05. To reduce costs, Fairchild opened its first foreign plant in Hong Kong, designed to manage the planned volume and, in collaboration with this, developed its first plastic packaging for the order (TO-92). Before that, all 1211 were packed as most transistors were at the time, in a metal box sealed with hermetically sealed (smelt metal glass) (TO-5). Once Fairchild activated production, he was able to lower the price to $0.50 and in two years (in 1965), he made 90% of the market share for UHF tunas and the new 1211 plastic generated 10% of the total profit. In 1965, it was also the year Dr. Moore wrote the article that was later called "Moore's Law". The lesson of transistor 1211 on how to effectively exploit the low marginal costs to increase volume was tangent in Dr. Moore's article. However, when it was associated with the propheticization of Moore's Law that correctly predicted that the cost of transistors on an integrated circuit would fall rapidly as manufacturing technology progressed, the half-conductor business model was have freely flooded the industry. Moore's Law in Processors: In 1968, three years after the publication of the Moore Act, Dr. Moore and Dr. Noyce, who were given the invention of the integrated circuit (CI) in 1959, left Fairchild to create Intel (INTC). They were quickly joined by Dr. Andy Grove, who, with his chemical engineering training, led the manufacturing operations at Intel. After Dr. Noyce and Dr. Moore, Dr. Grove was named the third Intel PDG in 1987. Intel began to manufacture static random access memory devices (SRAM) for central computers (the semi-conductor memory was part of Moore’s Law’s predictions), but quickly developed integrated circuits for displays and calculators, and was able to has passed from this to processors for general use. To optimize continuity, I will focus mainly on the evolution of Intel processors in this section. The first Intel processor, the 4-bit 4004, was released in 1971. It was manufactured using 10,000 2.250 nm manufacturing technology and consisted of 12 XNUMX transistors on an XNUMX mm. dier ( 187.5 transistors per mm ). Intel followed this one year later with its first 8-bit processor, 8008. He used the same process technology as the 4004, but with a better location and a better router, he had 3,500 14 transistors on an XNUMX mm. dieir (250 transistors by mm Intel launched his first 16-bit processor, the 8086  e x86 that continues to dominate personal computer and data center applications today. A year later, Intel launched the 8088, which was almost identical to 8086, but used an 8-bit external data bus, making it much more cost-effective to use in the first IBM PC. The 8086 and 8088 were made using a process of 3,000 29,000 nm and both had 33 XNUMX transistors on an XNUMX mm dier (879 transistors per mm ). What is not widely known or appreciated is that the 8086 and 8088s developed such a large design base outside the PC market that Intel manufactured the two integrated circuits until 1998. Intel released 32,80386 bits in 1985, which was manufactured using a process of 1,500,275,000 nm and with 104 XNUMX transistors and a NUMX size matrix (2.644x of all of this luminescence), which is all over the world. This is the first time I remember reading a Wall Street prediction that Moore's law was dead. It's been several years since I realized that Wall Street's views on the semiconductor industry were almost always false, but this is going into another story for another time... As the current Intel PDG, Patrick (Pat) Gelsinger covers in this related article: "Pat Gelsinger takes us on a journey in the past - and a vision of the future" Over the years, Moore's law has continued; sometimes they work more effectively than others, but consistently when they are considered in the longer term. To facilitate a little progress in the Moore's Law, the following table shows the PC processors manufactured on the different processes from 1,000 nm to 1989 nm from 2015 to 14. Since I don't have a reliable source of data beyond XNUMX nm for Intel , I stopped there. Processor An Process Production Table of Mother Transistor Count transistors by mm 1.000m 173 mm 1.2 million Pentium 800nm 294 mm 3.1 million-per 500m3mm 507 mm 5.5 mm 5.5 million 5.5 million 5.5 million 5.5 million 2.5 million 2.5 million  ion Pentium IV Willamette 180m 217 mm 42 million Pentium IV Northwood 130m 145 mm 55 million Pentium IV Prescott 110 110 112 million Moulin C65nm 90 nm 40 nm 40 400 400 400 400 400 400 m2 60 m2 400 100 m2 100 m2 60m2 7 000 100 m2 60m2 7 000 100 m3 112 million Mulin C 65m 90 nm 40 nm 40 400 400 400 400 400 m2 400 m2 400 m2 400 m2 400 m2 400m2 600 m3 100m2 110 m2 65m2 400 nm 400 400 400 m3 100m2 100 m2 60m2 700 nm 400 nm 400 nm 400 m2 400m 40m 40m 40m 40m 40m 4 illions Pont Core i7 ivy 22nm 160 mm 1.400 million i7 Broadway 14nm 133 mm 1.900 million This table and the above data show that Intel increased the density of transistors (transitors by 4 0 000 m20 ) 40  its first processor (7) and its iXNUMX Broadway Core. When we look at integrated server circuits (on the contrary to only PC processors in the above table), we can see a significantly higher number of transistors and much larger stack sizes. Intel released its first processor at $2 billion, the 64-bit Quad-core Itanium Tukwilla in 2010 using its 65 nm process. With the large cache memory, the size of the matrix was 699 mm 2.86 million transistors per mm Intel then crossed the 5 billion-billion-dollar barrier in 2012 with the Xeon Phi for special use. It was manufactured using a 22 nm process on a mass of 720 mm of death (6.9 million transistors per mm ). It's the largest matrix size I can find for an Intel processor. Xeon Phi is one of the three monolithic processors I found that used a matrix size greater than 700 mm . The other two are Fujitsu SPARC VII manufactured on a 20 nm process in 2017, which used a huge 795 mm mmm (795 mm)  ), and the AMD (AMD) produced on a 14 nm process using a slightly smaller 768 mm die, but with the smaller manufacturing process, it had a much higher transitor density (25 million transversis per mm). The Oracle (ORCL) SPARC M7 was probably larger than Fujitsu SPARC VII, but I could not find matrix data for the Oracle processor. Intel has a long history of more conservative presentation of its manufacturing processes, which explains why its 22 nm transistor density is roughly the same as Fujitsu for its 20 nm SPARC processor. While the time of microprocessors approaching the size of a postage stamp has been revolutionized, progress in manufacturing technology continues to allow for a growing density of transistors. The highest density I can quantify today for a processor is the Apple (AAPL) M1-Max that has 57 billion transistors on its 432 mm die (131.9 million transistors per mm) and is made using TSM5 technology (TSM) and 131.9 million  The density of Apple M1-Max transistors is more than 700,000 4004 times that of the first Intel XNUMX processor, and from a technical point of view, it shows that Moore's double-digitity is still more than good; it is still not a good idea to A slower rate than before. However, while the density of transistors will continue to increase, two things have happened during the recent advances in manufacturing technology that it is important to understand. First of all, my contacts tell me that the increasingly low cost curve by transistor that was the economic engine of Moore's Law for more than 50 years began to sneeze after the 10 nm manufacturing node. This means that the days when the cheaper transistors compensate for the rapid increase in fixed costs to design and produce a new integrated circuit are at least counted, or even revolutionised. This means that if Moore's main economic engine is not dead, he is under respiratory assistance. Secondly, the data show that processors have moved away from the massive matrix sizes introduced between 2012 and 2017, and even the main processors such as AMD and Intel have adopted Chipplet strategies. In the case of Intel Ponte Vecchio, the design includes 47 Chiplts using a variety of manufacturing technologies. The king is dead, long life to the king! Deficiency of faults (D ) for a given manufacturing process is defined as the number of defects per silicon plate, divided by the surface of the plate, which are large enough to be classified as "torent" defects for the target manufacturing process. The problem is that, as the size of the manufacturing process (production point) decreases, the size of what is considered a “your” defect also decreases. In general, a stochastic defect is defined as a defect that represents 20% of the size of the manufacturing node. For example, a defect less than 9 nm can be acceptable for the 45 nm manufacturing node, but a defect greater than 2.8 nm would be defined as a "biter" defect for the 14 nm manufacturing node. For the 5 nm manufacturing node, a defect measuring only 1 nm could be a killer. This is one of the main reasons why it has become increasingly difficult to produce large integrated monolithic circuits (such as those measured in the juice zone) when using a cutting-edge manufacturing technology. . We can see evidence from the above data that shows that the size of the processors has culminated in the six-year period from 2012 to 2017, when the art state was moving from 22 nm to 14 nm. Memory devices, GPGPs, GPUs and some specialized automatic learning circuits (ML) are subject to the same performance challenges. However, in these integrated circuits, you will find billions of identical cells (functional blocks) that are literally identical to each other. To optimize returns, these integrated circuits that still use monstrosity matrix sizes are usually designed with reagent cells that can be masked or programmed to replace non-remitted cells. It is not clear whether this trend will continue. There is a variety of opinions about when the density of errors has become an insurmountable problem. However, according to what I have read, it seems to have entered the equation in the window from 22 nm to 14 nm, and under 14 nm, the data suggest that it has become significant, and beyond, a problem that would only get worse. Since an integrated large-scale well-sized circuit is more likely to have a defect within its borders than a small well; there is a reverse correlation between the size of the matrix and performance, and the trend will become even more contradictory to that manufacturing technology will move towards ever-increasing nodes. This problem was highlighted by TSMC during the second quarter when it was running test plates for its new 2020 nm manufacturing unit. Following these tests, TSMC indicated its average performance for a 5mm that was about 80%, but this performance fell dramatically to only 32% for a 100 mm death. As has been the case throughout Moore's Law, TSM has improved its performance since these first tests, but I am sure that the 5 nm yield is still less favourable than the performance at higher manufacturing cores and the trend is clear; the  large monolithic branches are revolutionized. Several years before TSMC published the first data on its 5 nm process, the AMD's DPD, Dr. Lisa Su, presented the problem of default density in a very simple graph at the IEEE International Electronic Devices 2017. Meeting (IDEM). This chart shows the cost increase per mm produced for a 250mm matrix size while AMD was moving from 45 nm to smaller manufacturing nodes. The under-estimation conclusion is that the increase in the size of the matrix becomes problematic economically, and once you fall below 14/16 nm, the cost is significantly higher. The density of errors is not a new problem - it has literally existed since the first day. However, the lessons learned have always pushed it beyond the current manufacturing core and the ability to solve the current core performance problems is what has guided Moore's law for more than 50 years. Although you can be sure that continuous efforts are being made to reduce the impact of the default density on the high-end manufacturing nodes, five reasons suggest that the Chiplet trend is not only there to stay, but that it is also about developing quickly and to allow new market opportunities. (1) There have been very significant investments in the Chipplets to reduce assembly costs and optimize performance. Although there are inherent penalties in terms of costs and performance when you move away from a single-purpose single-use silicone design, it seems that performance penalties will be minimized and cost penalties will be more than offset when the technology ie Chiplt will be fully exploited. (2) The Universal Chipplet Interconnect Express (UCI) has specified a deto-die connection standard to establish an open Chiplt ecosystem. The founding members of the consortium include: ASE , DMLA, Bras Google Cloud , Intel, Méta, Microsoft, Quantum, Samsung and TSMC . IUIe is similar to the PCI specification that standardizes the computer interfaces. However, UCIe offers up to 100 times more bandwidth, a 10 times lower bandwidth and energy efficiency 10 times better than the IPC. With this standard in place, I think we will see a fleet of new Chipplets arriving on the market. (3) With the release of its CHIPS Program (common Heterogeneous Integration and Intellectual Property Resus Strategy) in 2017, the Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency (DAARPA) was on the front line of the Chipplet curve. The objective of CHIPS is to develop a broad catalogue of third-party Chiplets for commercial purposes and military applications that, according to DARPA's forecasts, will result in a 70% reduction in costs and time for implementation of new concepts. CHIPS DARPA The program goes beyond the exploitation of the benefits of incorporating heterogen manufacturing nodes to also incorporate etherogenic materials into a Chiplt design. (4) Moore's law magic was that the cost of manufacturing by transistors would decrease much more than fixed costs were rising as manufacturing technology progressed. I do not find any data to quantify this, but I can find a broad agreement that the downward cost curve has been 10 nm high and that it is heading in a negative direction. As the cost of advanced manufacturing increases, a Chiplt strategy allows integrated circuit architects to target the high (cost) manufacturing nodes only for the Chiplt concepts that absolutely need the highest performance available to them. and target other parts of the Chiplet concepts towards low-power and/or low cost manufacturing processes. (5) The design of the pots may accelerate marketization, reduce fixed costs, reduce overall manufacturing costs for a particular design and take advantage of architectures that can be extended and/or modified over time. In other words, the Chiplt concepts offer unique flexibility that is not economically viable in monolithic concepts. This trend will become more apparent and will accelerate as we see the introduction of new Chipplets in accordance with the ITU. Not only are manufacturers facing a challenge of performance of default density that has a direct correlation with the size of the matrix, as you can see on the following graph, the fixed costs associated with the design and production of a new integrated circuit Complex monolithics have been smouldering with the progress of manufacturing technology. In other words, the data suggest that we have reached a bottom-up point and Chipplet is the answer; not only to the challenges of performance and higher costs, but also to enable the semiconductor industry to open up new market opportunities. Although I am focusing on this article on integrated processor circuits (mainly Intel processors for continuity reasons), the increase in fixed costs and the reverse correlation between yields and the size of the plugs also have an impact on the concepts of the e systems on the socket (SoC). There is already evidence that MediaTek will move to a Chiplit 3 nm design with TSMC for its application processor (AP) for smartphone and I am convinced that Quantcomm has a Chiplet design brass that he has not yet made public. With the UCI and the DARPA CHIPS program, manufacturers of SOC that target the wide range of markets beyond access points for smartphones will adopt tips to reduce costs, shorten development cycles and increase flexibility. This will open up new opportunities for support software manufacturers and a wide variety of IP companies. I believe that we will also see intellectual property companies expand their traditional market approach by taking advantage of the new IUI specification to “enforce” their known intellectual property (KGD) and effectively sell their intellectual property in the form of n that directs the manufacturers of semi-conductors and integrated circuit manufacturing companies. as well as OEM customers who develop their own specific chip for application. I think one of the most interesting things that the Chipplets will allow is the new markets that do not have the volume or are too fragmented to generate a multi-million dollar investment in a monolithic IC design. These include a wide variety of IoT, AI and Machine Learning (ML) opportunities where FPGA technology can be used for accelerators that can adapt quickly to changing algorithms and provide the flexibility of design to expand the market and the Life cycle SoC. The plugs can also allow new and existing SoC solutions to the new and existing markets by providing sophisticated processor solutions and other specific options to the client (add more processor hearts, adding an accelerator, adding more memory, even changing/ day the RF section for a new standard, etc.) . These types of changes and flexibility were virtually impossible with the concepts of integrated monolithic circuits. Bottom Line: Without the benefit of lowering variable costs (low manufacturing costs by transistor) compensates for the significantly higher fixed costs and increased fault density complications, Moore's law is reversed as we know it. However, as in the past, the semi-conductor ecosystem is adapting and as Chiplt technology gains ground, we will most likely be seeing a period of accelerated innovation and the opening up of new market opportunities as we move forward. The point here (the basic point if you want) is that the Chipplets open new doors to the creativity and the continuous expansion of technology in our way of living and working. We have reached a point where we no longer need to think only about what makes sense for the concepts of integrated monolithic circuits that are hampered by ultra-roasted fixed costs and extremely long delivery times; we can now concentrate on the Heterogen fibers that benefit from new open standards to optimize the concepts for the cost and final performance dictated by the use case. When you associate these new benefits with the standardization of the UCIA and DARPA CHIPS program, there is great potential for opening up new markets and new use cases that have not even seen the back of a cocktail napkin. stories.body:
We are still bearish and remain sell-rated on Spotify (NYSE:SPOT). Consistent with our bearish April piece, Spotify is trading at about $87, dropping 71% below its 52-week high and 43% below when we first wrote about it. While Spotify built an excellent music business, we believe the company won't be able to generate profits soon. We believe Spotify has to deal with churn due to inflationary pressures, turbulence in Europe and Asia, and currency issues. We also don't believe the company has the balance sheet to keep up with the competition meaningfully. We believe the company must spend heavily to keep up with the competition, and profits will likely remain elusive in the near term. Therefore, investors should use any rally in the shares to exit their positions

Despite Spotify's better-than-expected 2Q22 report, we still recommend investors sell shares. For 2Q22, Spotify reported a total of 433M users across both its ad-supported and premium accounts - an 11 million increase compared to its 422M in 1Q22. While subscription growth this quarter seems like a major win compared to the subscription slowdown in 1Q22, we do not believe the positive momentum could last.

Spotify also guided higher for 3Q22. While we share the company's belief that subscribers will grow, we believe this growth will NOT offset materially higher spending in 3Q22. We don't believe it is a question of whether Spotify will be able to increase subscriber growth; instead, we believe it is a question of whether the company can generate lasting profitability.

Given the macro and currency headwinds, we expect Spotify churn to remain elevated and possibly increase over the next few months. We do not expect Spotify to generate meaningful profits soon, making the stock very difficult to own.

The following graph outlines Spotify's net losses despite steady subscriber growth.

We believe Spotify is stuck in a cycle of needing to spend money to see growth, while its competition is not. Spotify spent $391M on sales and marketing, amounting to 14% of total revenue.

The following table from 2Q22 outlines Spotify's operating losses this past quarter.

Spotify operates in a highly competitive market. Spotify is in a difficult position as it lacks a competitive advantage. Spotify's competition includes YouTube (GOOG) (GOOGL), Amazon Music (AMZN), Apple Music (AAPL), and a host of smaller players in several countries. Spotify's larger competitors are not as focused on generating profits in their music streaming business as Spotify is and can spend heavily to acquire content and subscribers. We remain concerned about Spotify's market share as its main competitors have the advantage of other revenue streams to fall back on, while Spotify does not. Competition, including Apple and Amazon, can bundle their music and audio content with their other services. Spotify does not own the content it streams; hence, the company struggles to make money without content over a longer period and a consistent edge to leverage subscribers. We see Spotify ramping up spending to maintain subscription growth, while competition is not necessarily sharing that struggle.

In addition, Spotify faces specifically heated competition in the podcast field with Apple Podcasts, Google Podcasts (including YouTube), Deezer (EPA: DEEZR), and Audible. Apple's collection of 90 million labels is the largest in the industry. Michelle and Barack Obama left Spotify podcasts in April for Spotify's competitor Audible, and only last month, the final episode of Reply All, one of Spotify's most popular podcasts, aired. Spotify offers a total of 82M tracks, which include 4.4 million podcasts. We believe Spotify needs to bring its A-game to keep up with the competition.

While both Spotify and its competition are down YTD, Spotify still underperforms more than others. YTD, Apple stock declined around -20%, Amazon -30%, Alphabet -32% while Spotify dropped about -62%. We expect Spotify's competition, including YouTube, Apple Music, and Amazon Music, to continue outperforming the company as they have YTD. The following chart shows Spotify's performance YTD among competitors

Spotify has been down almost 33% over the past five years. Aside from underperforming peers on YTD and five-year metrics, Spotify declined 61% over the last year, underperforming the S&P 500 Index (SPY), which dropped 18%. We believe the stock will continue to drop as we see no clear growth catalysts in the near term. YTD, the stock is down by around 62%. Spotify is approaching its 52-week-low of around $88, down 71% from its high of $306. We would not be surprised if Spotify goes below $75 over the next few months on worsening macro, churn, and intensifying competition.

The following charts show Spotify's performance over the past five years among competitors and during the last year.

Spotify is relatively cheap, but we don't recommend buying the stock on weakness. On a P/E basis, the company has negative earnings; hence, the P/E metric cannot be used for valuation. On the EV/Sales basis, Spotify is trading 1.1x EV/Sales on C2023 revenue versus the peer group average of 2.1x. Spotify needs to find a way to become profitable quickly. Until then, we believe the company is at the mercy of the markets. We recommend investors sell the stock at current levels.

The following chart illustrates Spotify's valuation relative to its peer group.

Out of 31 analysts covering the stock, 16 are buy-rated, 14 are hold-rated, and the remaining are sell-rated. Spotify is trading around $88, consistent with our April prediction that the stock would drop below the $100 mark. Median and mean sell-side price targets are $141, with a potential upside of about 60%. The following charts illustrate the sell-side ratings and price targets for Spotify.

We continue to view Spotify as a challenged business. Spotify continues to face enormous headwinds, particularly associated with the macro and intense competition in various countries. With the world in turmoil and the advertising business challenge, we believe Spotify stock is at the risk of continued sell-off. We believe Spotify is still under pressure from the global macroeconomic environment and intense competition in developed and emerging economies. While we believe the company can achieve subscription growth in 3Q22, we are not optimistic about Spotify's ability to generate meaningful and lasting profitability. We do not see the stock recovering meaningfully in the near term. We recommend investors exit the stock at current levels.

stories.body:
Recessions tend to be tough on risk assets. Stocks normally take a major tumble starting before the recession is visible and begin to recover before the recession ends. It's pretty much inevitable. Not every market decline is linked to a recession but pretty much every recession is accompanied by a decline in stocks. That being said, not all stocks react in the same way. Stocks with products consumers can't do without (consumer staples, utilities, financials, and health care) often do better while industry areas like consumer discretionary, which encompasses products customers can do without, generally do worse. The categories of "growth" and 'value" divide the market as a whole into broad categories that tend to underperform or outperform in "ordinary" recessions. To simplify the comparison, I am going to use the Vanguard Growth ETF (NYSEARCA:VUG) and the Vanguard Value ETF (NYSEARCA:VTV) to define the categories.

VUG and VTF are helpful because both use the CRSP (Center For Research in Security Prices) indexes developed by the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. Six factors define "growth": long and short term earnings growth, 3-year historical growth in sales and earnings, the ratio of investment to assets, and return on assets. It's all about the future and contains nothing about valuations. All five defining "value" factors involve price and valuation: book to price, 3-year future earnings to price, 3-year historical earnings to price, dividend to price, and sales to price. (The terms invert common parlance.) With one exception "value" is firmly fixed in the present and not the future. Those factors will frame the discussion of probable performance in a recession.

One thing to bear in mind is that not all recessions are alike. It has actually been quite a while since the economy had a garden variety recession stemming from an overheated economy which led the Fed to "take away the punchbowl," as the saying goes, "just when the party started to rock." The last three recessions each had a very specific theme. The 2000-2003 recession was mild despite the fact that it was accompanied and to some degree driven by a powerful crash of overpriced dot-com stocks. Value stocks did very well with a rally which remained under the radar. VTV and VUG did not exist at that time.

The 2007-2009 crash accompanying the Great Recession was driven by low quality mortgage debt which almost pulled the financial system under. Because housing and financials are prominent in value funds, value investors took a shellacking along with growth. One of the stalwart value funds, Dodge and Cox Stock Fund (DODGX), was badly beaten up because it had too much faith in traditional value areas. Here's a chart of the performance of VUG, VTV, and DODGX from just before to just after the crash and crisis:

What you see in the above graph is that everything got crushed. There was nowhere to hide. If you look closely, however, you will see that growth held up longer and stopped going down sooner than value prefiguring strong leadership in the recovery. Stocks and market sectors which outperform in recessions often emerge as long term winners afterward. The Dodge and Cox Stock Fund, which deserved its reputation as a fund that outperformed in hard times, was actually hit a little harder than the value index. Its error resided in the belief that the 2008-2009 event would resemble the past. I spent some time thinking about that mistake because I managed money professionally at the time and had several clients in DODGX.

The most recent recession, the brief downturn involving the COVID lockdown, was the strangest of the three recent recessions. Unemployment went up quickly to 15% before powerful help from the government kicked in. The stock downturn was sharp but lasted only a month. Many tech companies thrived in an environment when an increasing amount of business took place online. Here are the charts for VTV and VUG:

As the chart shows, growth fell about equally as hard as value. This is due in part to the fact that it had been outperforming value before the crash and was probably due for a correction in any case, but there are no asterisks needed to explain the way that VUG blasted off from the bottom. Powered by technology and new business models and fueled by exceptional liquidity and low rates it opened a huge performance gap from the March 20 low to the end of 2021. Taken in sum, the performance of value stocks and growth stocks in the three most recent recessions show that there may be no hard and fast rule as to which performs better in a down market accompanied by a recession. A deeper look might provide some factors to consider in the event we are currently in or about to enter a recession.

Most informed investors believe value outperforms in recessions, but it didn't in two of the three major recessions discussed above. A fair amount depends upon what was going on before the recession, an example being the extreme dot.com bubble in the years before 2000 which made all techs and many blue chip market leaders wildly overpriced. Value generally didn't help in the Great Recession of 2008-2009, but there's the idiosyncratic example of Walmart (WMT) which was helped enormously as consumers traded down to their value prices. WMT was actually up about 18% for the duration of the crisis which took the market as a whole down over 50%. Here's a picture of WMT's outperformance:

Idiosyncratic examples aside, value stocks might perform better for a couple of reasons:

Here are the relative weights of industry groups in the Value Index:

Of the four industry groups with double digit percentages three are classic defensive areas unlikely to be harmed by an ordinary recession. Industrials are somewhat more cyclical. Energy might well be defensive in a present recession because of the global shortage. Utilities, on the other hand, have only a 6.28% representation despite being very much defensive (the use of electric power will only decline slightly mainly because of diminished use in manufacturing). That's the total value of all traded utilities, by the way. They are not included in the growth index.

These are the top ten stocks in the value index as of August 31: United Health (UNH), Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A)(BRK.B), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), ExxonMobil (XOM), JP Morgan (JPM), Procter & Gamble (PG), Eli Lilly (LLY), Pfizer (PFE), Coca-Cola (KO). No single stock has representation higher than 3% of the index. If you are surprised to see United Health ranked above Berkshire Hathaway, which has a significantly larger market cap, the reason is that the CRSP indexes sometimes split company caps between the growth and value indexes. Berkshire apparently has about 20% more of its market allocated to growth than United Health. In general the top ten value stocks have qualities suggesting why they might do better in the event of an ordinary recession as do the top three industry weightings. They also might serve as ideas for investors who prefer individual stocks.

At this point it might be helpful to consider how value and growth have performed going into the present moment:

Starting in November-December of 2021 Value began to Outperform Growth. The question is whether after over a decade of Growth leadership Value began to outperform and will continue to do so going into and coming out of a recession. Or has the outperformance of Value over recent months reduced the valuation advantage for Value and put Growth in a position to resume leadership?

Growth has outperformed the market since emerging as the leader following the 2008-2009 Crash and Great Recession. Coming out of the COVID lockdown growth companies widened the gap as both new and established companies with products and services not requiring physical contact took advantage of the lockdown. A lower tier of growth stocks without present earnings (and in some cases very expensive by the measure of price to sales) led the latter stages of the rally. Yet while valuations were quite high they did not approach the levels of absurdity seen in the dot.coms in the years leading to 2000. Additionally, compared to the 2000 Bubble, many of the growth companies had real products, strong revenues, and real earnings.

Adding it all up, growth companies were expensive but in the aggregate less unrealistically priced than "growth" companies in 2000. If it turns out that we are entering a recession at the present moment, growth stock valuations will go forward with 33% cheaper valuations because of the decline for the past year (as shown in the above chart). In addition to that, investors should bear in mind that growth stocks have led coming out of the past two major downturns, and in one of the two cases (2007-2009) actually took over market leadership during and after the recession. Here are the percentages of industries which make up the growth index:

The growth index is dominated by just three industries: technology, consumer cyclical, and communication. Together the three groups make up 73% of the index. That gives you a good idea of where growth has been in the US economy over the past 15 years. These are the top ten stocks included in the growth index.: Apple (AAPL). Microsoft (MSFT). Amazon (AMZN), Tesla (TSLA), Alphabet Class A (GOOG)(GOOGL), Alphabet Class C, Meta (META), NVIDIA (NVDA), VISA (V), The Home Depot (HD).

There are several reasons growth companies might perform better:

You can make a pretty good case that it doesn't pay to turn a portfolio upside down in an effort to own things which will perform well in the course of a particular market environment. An overall portfolio should be built to work reasonably well in all economic conditions. It should contain both growth and value. The two categories have alternated as market leaders over time, with periods of leadership lasting from 7 to 10 years or so. That may be long enough for determined trend followers to overweight one side or the other. It would certainly have paid off handsomely to overweight growth from 2010 to early 2021. Hindsight, as a shrewd investor used to tell me, is always 20-20. Investors who lack functioning crystal balls do best with a portfolio that will do reasonably well in most environments with a bit of tweaking and pruning from time to time. Is there a way to capture the best of both approaches?

In the section on value I pointed out that United Health ranked above Berkshire Hathaway despite the fact that Berkshire has a market cap about $100 billion greater. The explanation is that Berkshire is primarily a value stock but also meets many of the criteria for growth. For that matter, United Health probably is similarly a value stock which also fits the growth model. In this earlier article I pointed out that United Health and Apple (the number one growth company) had statistical metrics so similar that if you removed the name and absolute amounts (Apple being much bigger) the ratios are so much alike that it would be hard to know which company was being described.

There are in fact 347 companies in the Vanguard Value ETF and 262 companies in the Growth ETF. That's a total of 609 stocks in two indexes made up from the S&P 500. The "500" often has a few more or less than 500, but not to that degree. It shows that quite a few companies fit both sets of criteria well enough to be included at different amounts in both indexes. The CRSP indexes in fact have a detailed protocol by which this sharing in two indexes is calculated.

In the course of the more than ten years when growth led value by a large margin a number of well-established actively managed "value" funds found ways to classify growth stocks as value. I began to notice this three or four years ago and one well-known and highly successful value manager I noticed doing this is Bill Nygren of Oakmark whose explanation for including growth stocks in his Oakmark Fund and Oakmark Select Fund sounded pretty much like a combination of the six CRSP growth factors with the five CRSP value factors. In short, the companies he included, Alphabet in both funds and Meta in the Select fund, could be described as cheap in context of their growth rates. Coming at it from another angle, maturing growth stocks tend to gradually slide to lower growth rates and while their P/E ratios decline in such a way as to make them increasingly resemble value stocks. I should add that this rarely if ever works in the other direction.

A confession: although I am basically a value investor, I also bought Alphabet near the market low in March 2020 and am up about 75% at this point though down spectacularly from the December 2021 high. When I bought it, its P/E was about the same as that of Coca-Cola, which has negative top line growth and earnings manufactured by share buybacks; what if offers is a nice dividend. That's a pure dead-in-the-water value stock. To hold Alphabet or buy it now one would have to believe that it is likely to do as well as Coca-Cola and other consumer staples. While Alphabet faces a few headwinds, I think it will likely do at least that. The easy and obvious approach for most investors is simply to own the growth and value ETFs in a proportion reflecting your view. The degree of commitment should reflect the odds as you perceive them. If your view is neutral you might buy equal amounts of VTV and VUG. For reasons I will explain below my own view is not neutral.

The best-fit model for the present situation is the period before and during, the recession of 2000-2003. Growth is overpriced and value looks more or less fairly priced. The valuation of growth is much less extreme than in 2000, but it is still high enough that valuation adjustment is likely to be one of the major themes of the present bear market. One of the issues with the growth index is that its top ten stocks add up to almost 50% of the index. For several years analysts, myself among them, have mentioned frequently how large a part of all major indexes (except value indexes) has come to be driven by the rising market cap of a half dozen or so large winners. The warning was that a day might come when this process would run in reverse.

That day has finally come.. the top four stocks in the Vanguard Growth ETF - Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, and Amazon - add up to 37% of the entire index. All of the four growth leaders except Amazon appear to be mature or maturing companies likely to have slowing growth rates and declining P/Es. Amazon may or may not experience slowing growth now or soon, but its P/E remains astronomical. It can do extremely well operationally and still see its stock price go down.

The current bear market in these VUG stocks is very much about excessive valuation which has to be worked off. Only then will there be a reduction in the risk that the top-heavy cap leaders will continue to pull the growth index down. Meanwhile no recent growth companies seem to be climbing the cap-weighted ladder as their replacements. Further down in the top ten both Nvidia and Meta are a lot cheaper than a year ago but face very major headwinds. In the first year of the 2008-2009 recession ad spending dropped double digits and in 2020 it stopped entirely. Given those facts neither Meta nor Alphabet look particularly defensive. Amazon, on the other hand, might be well positioned, like Walmart, against a downturn in consumer spending, but there's still that very high P/E.

To me, the odds in the event that we are entering a recession tilt toward value. Valuation is an important part of the picture, and value stocks in aggregate seem fairly valued. Some areas prominent in the value index seem significantly undervalued - financials and energy in particular. While neither VUG nor VTV is ranked Buy/Hold/Sell at SA, the Value ETF comes in at #47 out of 508 Equity ETFs as against #246 out of 508 for the Growth ETF. The numbers speak for themselves, saying that the algo which ranks equity ETFs prefers value. That sort of backs into a quant preference for value over growth, which coincides with my view.

sentences: Recessions tend to be tough on risk assets.

Taken in sum, the performance of value stocks and growth stocks in the three most recent recessions show that there may be no hard and fast rule as to which performs better in a down market accompanied by a recession.

If you are surprised to see United Health ranked above Berkshire Hathaway, which has a significantly larger market cap, the reason is that the CRSP indexes sometimes split company caps between the growth and value indexes.

In addition to that, investors should bear in mind that growth stocks have led coming out of the past two major downturns, and in one of the two cases (2007-2009) actually took over market leadership during and after the recession.
In the course of the more than ten years when growth led value by a large margin a number of well-established actively managed "value" funds found ways to classify growth stocks as value.

stories.title: VTV Vs VUG: Entering A Recession, Is Value Or Growth Better?

stories.body:
Apple Inc. ( AAPL, Financial) is one of the most recognizable brands on earth as well as one of the most popular stocks in the investor community. The company produces products such as the iPhone, iPad, Apple Watch and, most recently, Apple TV devices and Apple TV+ streaming services.

The iPhone collection represented the large product line at 49% of total revenues in the most recent quarter. Geographically, the company generates roughly 45% of its revenue from the Americas, with the remainder earned elsewhere in the world, particularly China, which represents over 17% of the company’s revenues. Most of the Apple ecosystem is run on its own internally developed software and semiconductors.

Although the Apple iOS is gaining market share, the Android system still represents about 70% of global cell phone usage. However, in the U.S., the Apple iOS represents about 57% of all smartphone sales.

Apple is expected to generate global sales of $392 billion in the fiscal year ending September 2022. Apple’s market capitalization is a stunning $2.3 trillion and represents approximately 7.0% of the S&P 500 index. Recent negative news has gotten the stock down, causing some investors to see a value opportunity here, but I think Apple is still overvalued.

A recent Bank of America ( BAC, Financial) Securities report identified current issues that may negatively impact Apple stock. These include a weaker iPhone 14 cycle as consumer spending slows down around the world, slower growth in the Services segment (particularly in the areas of the App Store and other licensing arrangements) and a decrease in gross profit levels in the near-term. The current report also mentioned a reversion to normalized levels for iPad an Mac sales that saw a Covid-19 pandemic boost as well as pressure on earnings from the stronger dollar.

The company recently reported fiscal third-quarter results for the period ending June 2022. Revenues increased 1.8% to $82.9 billion and gross profits increased 1.7%. Operating income declined 4.3% to $23.1 billion.

Company management stated, “Our June quarter results continued to demonstrate our ability to manage our business effectively despite the challenging operating environment. We set a June quarter revenue record and our installed base of active devices reached an all-time high in every geographic segment and product category.”

As usual, Apple continues to generate high levels of free cash flow. For the nine-month period ending June 2022, the company generated $98.0 billion in operating cash flow and capital expenditures were $7.4 billion. With over $90 billion in free cash flow, the company used $65 billion to repurchase shares and $11 billion in dividend payments.

The company has a fortress balance sheet with cash and investments totaling $179 billion and total debt of $120 billion.

Consensus analyst earnings per share estimates for the fiscal year ending September 2022 are $6.10, but for the following fiscal year ending September 2023, earnings per share are expected to decline to below $6.00 due to product cycles. The puts Apple stock trading at 23 times this year's earnings expectations and 24 times next year's. The forward enterprise-value-to-Ebitda ratio is in the range of 18 to 19.

Those valuations are too high for a company that manufactures high priced consumer items in my opinion. The average cost to purchase an iPhone is over $750, and although there is a widespread irrational loyalty by consumers, it’s still a luxury item.

The GuruFocus discounted cash flow calculator provides a fair value of $108 for Apple stock using $6.10 in EPS as the starting point and assuming a generous 10% long-term growth rate.

Apple’s below-average dividend yield is only 0.61% currently.

Gurus who have purchased Apple stock recently include Ken Fisher (Trades, Portfolio) and Private Capital (Trades, Portfolio). Gurus who have sold or reduced their Apple positions include the Parnassus Endeavor Fund (Trades, Portfolio) and Mario Gabelli (Trades, Portfolio).

Apple's earnings will likely decline next year, so I don't think the stock deserves to be valued at high forward multiples like it currently is. Apple is no longer a growth stock but a consumer cyclical whose operating results will fluctuate with product cycles and economic cycles. As this fact is accepted by more investors, valuation levels will likely drift lower. I believe Apple would be fairly valued with a mid-teens price-earnings ratio, which would put the stock price closer to $100 per share.

Día en negativo para el Russell 2000, que terminó el día del viernes 30 de septiembre con leves bajadas del 0,61%, hasta los 1.664,72 puntos. El Russell 2000 llegó a un volumen máximo de 1.707,75 puntos y un mínimo de 1.664,27 puntos. El rango de cotización para el Russell 2000 entre su punto más alto y el más bajo (máximo-mínimo) durante este día se situó en el 2,55%.

Si consideramos los datos de los últimos siete días, el Russell 2000 acumula un descenso del 0,89%, por ello en términos interanuales mantiene aún una disminución del 24,48%. El Russell 2000 se sitúa un 26,75% por debajo de su máximo del presente año (2.272,56 puntos) y un 0,9% por encima de su cotización mínima en lo que va de año (1.649,84 puntos).

Un índice bursátil es un indicador que deja ver cómo evoluciona el valor de un determinado conjunto de activos, para lo cual recolecta datos de varias compañías o sectores de una parte del mercado.

Estos indicadores son usados principalmente por las bolsas de valores de diversos países y cada uno de ellos pueden integrarse por empresas con diferentes especificidades como podría ser contar con una capitalización bursátil similar o pertenecer a un mismo tipo de giro, también, hay algunos índices que sólo toman en cuenta un puño de acciones para determinar su valor u otras que consideran cientos de acciones.

Los índices bursátiles sirven como indicador de confianza en el mercado de valores, la confianza empresarial, la salud de la economía nacional y global y el rendimiento de las inversiones en acciones y participaciones de una entidad. Generalmente, si los inversionistas no tienen confianza, los costos de las acciones tienden a caer.

Asimismo, funcionan para medir el rendimiento de un gestor de activos y permiten a los inversores hacer una comparativa entre la rentabilidad y el riesgo; medir las oportunidades de un activo financiero o crear carteras.

Este tipo de indicadores comenzaron a usarse a finales del siglo XIX luego de que el periodista Charles H. Dow. observara con detenimiento cómo las acciones de las empresas tendían a subir o bajar juntas de precio, por lo que creó dos índices: uno que contenía a las 20 compañías ferroviarias más importantes (pues era la industria más importante de la época), así como 12 acciones de otros tipos de negocios

Actualmente hay diversos índices y pueden congregarse en función de su ubicación geográfica, los sectores, el tamaño de las compañías o incluso el tipo de activo, por ejemplo, el índice estadounidense del Nasdaq está compuesto por las 100 mayores compañías mayormente relacionadas a la tecnologías como Apple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOG), Tesla (TSLA), Nvidia (NVDA), PayPal (PYPL), Comcast (CMCSA), Adobe (ADBE).

Cada índice bursátil posee su propia forma de ser medido, pero el principal componente es la capitalización bursátil de cada empresa que lo integra. Este se obtiene al multiplicar el valor del día del bono en la bolsa correspondiente por el total de participaciones que están en en manos de los inversionistas.

Las firmas que cotizan en bolsa están obligadas a presentar un balance de su composición. Dicho informe debe salir a la luz cada tres o seis meses, según corresponda.

Leer un índice bursátil también requiere tener en cuenta sus cambios en el tiempo. Los nuevos índices siempre abren con un valor fijo basado en los precios de las acciones en su fecha de inicio, pero no todos siguen este método. Por ende, puede parecer engañoso.

Si un índice suma 500 puntos en un día, mientras que otro solo añade 20, podría parecer que el primero tuvo un rendimiento mejor. No obstante, si el primero comenzó el día en 30.000 puntos y el otro en 300, se puede concluir que, en términos porcentuales, las ganancias para el segundo fueron más grandes.

Entre los principales índices bursátiles estadounidenses está el Dow Jones Industrial Average, mejor conocido como Dow Jones, conformado por 30 compañías., el S&P 500, que engloba a 500 de las mayores empresas de la Bolsa de Nueva York. Finalmente, hay que mencionar el Nasdaq 100, que agrupa a 100 de las mayores firmas no financieras.

Por otro lado, los índices más importantes de Europa son el Eurostoxx 50, que abarca las 50 empresas más importantes de la eurozona. Por otro lado, el DAX 30, principal índice alemán que contiene a las compañías más descollantes de la Bolsa de Fráncfort; la FTSE 100 de la Bolsa de Londres; el CAC 40 de la Bolsa de París; y el IBEX 35, de la bolsa española.

En el continente asiático, los principales índices bursátiles son el Nikkei 225, compuesto por las 225 empresas más importantes de la bolsa de valores de Tokio. Asimismo, el SSE Composite Index, que puede considerarse el principal de China, conformado por las compañías más destacadas de la Bolsa de Shanghái. De igual manera, cabe mencionar el Hang Seung Index en Hong Kong y el KOSPI en Corea del Sur.

En lo que respecta a la región latinoamericana, se tiene el IPC, que contiene a las 35 firmas más sobresalientes de la Bolsa Mexicana de Valores (BMV). Al menos un tercio de ellas forman parte del patrimonio del magnate Carlos Slim.

Otro es el Bovespa, compuesto por las 50 empresas más importantes de la bolsa de Sao Paulo; el Merval de Argentina; el IPSA de Chile; el MSCI COLCAP de Colombia; el IBC de Caracas, conformado por 6 compañías de Venezuela.

De igual manera, existen otro tipo de índices bursátiles globales como el MSCI Latin America, que incluye las 137 empresas más importantes de Brasil, Chile, Colombia, México y Perú.

De igual forma, está el MSCI World, que incluye a 1600 compañías de 23 países desarrollados; el MSCI Emerging Markets, compuesto por más de 800 empresas de países en desarrollo; y el S&P Global 100, conformado por las 100 firmas multinacionales más poderosas de todo el planeta.

stories.title: Índice bursátil Russel 2000 registró pérdida de 0,61% este 30 de septiembre

en.body:
The 2000 Russell Day was a negative day, which ended on Friday, September 30, with lows of 0.61%, up to 1,664.72 points. Russell 2000 reached a maximum volume of 1,707.75 points and a minimum of 1,664.27 points. The rating for Russell 2000 between its highest point and the lowest (maximum) during this day was 2.55%.

If we look at the data of the last seven days, Russell 2000 is a 0.89% drop, so in terms of the annual rate, it still has a 24.48% decrease. Russell 2000 is 26.75% below its maximum of this year (2,272.56 points) and 0.9% above its minimum rate of annual quota (1.649.84 points).

A stock index is an indicator that allows you to see how the value of a particular set of assets evolves, for which it collects data from several companies or sectors of a part of the market.

These indicators are used mainly by the stock exchanges of various countries and each of them can be integrated by companies with different characteristics as they could be similar stock-capitalisation or belonging to the same type of circulation, also, there are some that only take into account a handful of actions to determine their value or other actions that they consider hundreds of shares.

Stock exchange rates serve as a indicator of confidence in the stock market, business confidence, the health of the national and global economy and the return of investments in an entity’s shares and shares. Generally, if investors don’t have confidence, the costs of the shares tend to fall.

They also work to measure the performance of an asset manager and allow investors to make a comparison between profitability and risk; measure the opportunities of a financial asset or create portfolios.

This type of indicator began to be used at the end of the 19th century after journalist Charles H. Dow. carefully observe how the companies’ actions tend to rise or fall price combinations, so it created two indicators: one containing the 20 most important railway companies (because it was the most important industry of the time), as well as 12 shares of other

There are currently various indicators and can be combined according to their geographical location, sectors, corporate size or even asset type, for example, the American Nasdaq index is composed of the 100 largest companies that are most closely related to co Apple Mo (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOG), Tesla (TSLA), Nvidia (NVDA), Paypal (PYPL), Comcast (CMSA), Adobe (ADBE).

Each stock index has its own way of being measured, but the main component is the stock exchange capitalisation of each company that integrates it. This is achieved by multiplying the value of the day of the bonus in the stock for the total of shares that are in the hands of investors.

The signatures listed in the stock exchange are obliged to present a balance of their composition. This report must be brought to light every three or six months, as appropriate.

Reading a stock index also requires taking into account your changes in time. New indices always open with a fixed value based on the prices of the shares on their starting date, but not everyone follows this method. So, it may seem misleading.

If a 500-point index in one day, while another only adds 20, it might seem that the first one had a better performance. However, if the first one started at 30,000 points and the other in 300, it can be concluded that, in percentage terms, the profits for the second were greater.

Among the major US stock index is the Dow Jones Industrial Average, best known as Dow Jones, consisting of 30 companies. The S&P 500, which includes 500 of the largest New York Stock Exchange companies. Finally, we must mention the Nasdaq 100, which is one of the largest non-financial signatures.

On the other hand, Europe’s most important indices are Eurostox 50, which covers the 50 most important companies in the eurozone. On the other hand, the DAX 30, the main German index that contains the most profitable companies in the Frankfurt Stock Exchange; the FTSE 100 of the London Stock Exchange; the CAC 40 of the Paris Stock Exchange; and the IBEX 35, of the Spanish

In the Asian continent, the main stock index is the Nikei 225, composed of the 225 most important companies in Tokyo's stock exchange. The SSE Component Index, which can be considered China’s main company, is formed by the most prominent Shanghai Stock Exchange companies. Similarly, the Hang Seung Index in Hong Kong and the KOSPI in South Korea can be mentioned.

As far as the Latin American region is concerned, there is the IPC, which contains the 35 most outstanding signatures of the Mexican Stock Exchange (BMV). At least one third of them are part of the heritage of the magnet Carlos Slim.

Another is the Bovespa, which is made up of the 50 most important companies in the Sao Paulo stock exchange; the Argentina Mercal; the Ipsa of Chile; the MSCI COLCAP of Colombia; the IBC of Caracas, composed of six Venezuelan companies.

Similarly, there is another type of global stock exchange rate such as the MSCI Latin America, which includes the 137 most important companies in Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.

Similarly, there is the MSCI World, which includes 1,600 companies from 23 developed countries; the MSCI Emerging Markets, consisting of more than 800 companies from developing countries; and the S&P Global 100, consisting of the 100 most powerful multinational firms
